Python has a number of useful data types beyond the built-in lists, tuples, dicts, and sets. In this tutorial, youâ€™ll learn all about the series of specialized container data types in the collections module from the Python standard library. Learning the collections module is a great way to level up your Python programming knowledge!

    • RALF GOMMERS

In accordance with PEP 632, distutils will be deprecated in Python 3.10 and in Python 3.12 it will be removed. This posed a big problem for SciPy, since itâ€™s build system depends on NumPyâ€™s distutils module â€” an extension of Pythonâ€™s built-in distutils. The SciPy maintainers set out to find a new build system and settled on Meson, which solves a number of build issues and even scores a 4x speed-up on build times!

  • Pythonâ€™s Operator æ¨¡å—çš„æœªçŸ¥åŠŸèƒ½
    • MARTIN HEINZ
    • â€¢ Shared by Martin Heinz

Have you heard of Pythonâ€™s operator module? It includes functions for common operators, including mathematical operators like +, -, *, and /, and well as operators for getting items from dictionaries and accessing object attributes. The operator module might seem confusing at first glance. This article explores why it exists, what benefits you get from it, and when it makes sense to use it in your code.

Ah, mutable default arguments. If you havenâ€™t come across them in your Python journey yet, this Reddit thread is full of examples of Python developers that lost time debugging functions with a mutable default argument. Avoiding mutable defaults is good advice in general, but blanket absolute statements are dangerous. To counter this discussion, hereâ€™s a Twitter thread exploring some genuine use cases.

Articles, Tutorials and Talks

In this tutorial, youâ€™ll get started with Pandas DataFrames, which are powerful and widely used two-dimensional data structures. Youâ€™ll learn how to perform basic operations with data, handle missing values, work with time-series data, and visualize data from a Pandas DataFrame.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • æµ‹è¯•å·®å¼‚
    • FILIPE XIMENES
    • â€¢ Shared by Filipe Ximenes

How do you write good tests? Itâ€™s a challenging problem because there are a number of layers involved. You need to write good test code that follows best practices. But you also need to write tests that arenâ€™t fragile and make sure tests really test what you expect them to. This article gives an example of a seemingly harmless test that turns out to be pretty fragile. Youâ€™ll learn one technique for making a test more robust called â€œtesting the diff.â€

  • ç¼–ç¨‹ä¸­çš„ç¾å¥½æ€æƒ³: Generators å’Œ Continuations
    • HSIN-HAO YU

This article explores how generators, which you can create in Python using the yield keyword in a function, are special cases of a more powerful construct called â€œcontinuations.â€ The author compares Pythonâ€™s generator syntax to creating continuations in Scheme, a modern LISP dialect. The idea isnâ€™t so much to learn how to write generators and continuations, but rather to explore how the ideas are related and to appreciate the elegance and beauty of both concepts.

Pagination breaks up results from a query into chunks called â€œpagesâ€ so that only a few results are returned to the user at a time. In many cases, using native SQL tools like LIMIT and OFFSET can get you up and running with pagination quickly and work fairly well. But on datasets with millions of rows, this method breaks down.
